review.title: Trust from the past: Bayesian Personalized Ranking based Link Prediction in Knowledge Graphs
review.abstract: Estimating the confidence for a link is a critical task for Knowledge Graph construction. Link prediction, or predicting the likelihood of a link in a knowledge graph based on prior state is a key research direction within this area. We propose a Latent Feature Embedding based link recommendation model for prediction task and utilize Bayesian Personalized Ranking based optimization technique for learning models for each predicate. Experimental results on large-scale knowledge bases such as YAGO2 show that our approach achieves substantially higher performance than several state-of-art approaches. Furthermore, we also study the performance of the link prediction algorithm in terms of topological properties of the Knowledge Graph and present a linear regression model to reason about its expected level of accuracy.
histories: SDM Workshop on Mining Networks and Graphs (MNG 2016), Miami, FL

metadata.title: Trust from the past: Bayesian Personalized Ranking based Link Prediction in Knowledge Graphs

sections.text: ar Xiv: 160 1.03 778v 1 [cs.L G] 14 Jan 20Estimating the reliability of a link is a critical task for knowledge graph construction. Link predicting or predicting the likelihood of a link in a knowledge chart based on the previous state is an important research direction in this area. We propose a latent feature embedding-based link recommendation model for prediction tasks and use Bayesian Personalized Ranking-based optimization technology for learning models for each predicate. Experimental results on large-scale knowledge bases such as YAGO2 show that our approach performs significantly better than secondary state-of-art approaches. In addition, we also examine the performance of the link prediction algorithm in terms of the opological properties of the knowledge graph and present a linear regression model to judge the expected level of accuracy.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: In terms of methodology, factorization and related variable models [3, 8, 14, 22, 25], the graphical model [15], and the Graphic Feature Method [18, 19], a large number of papers based on factorization models are discussed; the common denominator between the factorization methods is that they explain the triples of latent characteristics of enterprises. [2] This results in a tensor-based model that defines each entity and predicate in the form of a low dimensional effect. However, such a method is not suitable to take into account the symmetry property of the tensor.

sections.heading: 3 Background and Problem Statement
sections.text: Definition 1: We define the knowledge graph as a collection of triple facts G = (S, P, O), where s-S and o-O are the set of subjects and objects, and p-P is the set of predicates or relationships between them. G (s, p, o) = 1 if there is a direct connection of type p from s to o, and G (s, p, o) = 0 otherwise. Every triple fact in the knowledge graph is a statement interpreted as "A relation p between entities and o." For example, the statement "Kobe Bryant is an LA Lakers player" can be expressed by the following triple fact ("Kobe Bryant," "playsFor," "LA Lakers"). Definition 2: For each relationship p-P we define Gp (Sp, Op) as a two-part sub-curve of G, where the corresponding group of entities sp, op-Op are connected by relationship.

sections.heading: 4 Methods
sections.text: In this section, we describe our model, namely the latent feature Embedding Model with Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR) based optimization technology, which we propose for the task of link prediction in the knowledge graph. In our link prediction setting, we first construct its two-dimensional subgraph Gp (Sp, Op) and then learn the optimal low-dimensional embedding for the corresponding subjects and object units sp-Sp, op-Op by maximizing a ranking-based distance function. The learning process is based on stochastic gradient descent (SGD). The SGD-based optimization technique iteratively updates the low-dimensional representation of sp and op to convergence. Subsequently, the learned model is used for ranking the unobserved triple facts in descending order: triple facts with higher score values have a higher probability of representing true statements, of selecting higher reliability to perform them in the knowledge graph.

sections.heading: 4.1 Latent Feature Based Embedding Model
sections.text: For each predicate p, the model maps both the respective subject and the object sp and op into low-dimensional, continuous vector spaces, say Ups, IR 1 x K or V po, IR 1. We measure the compatibility between subject sp and object op as the point product of its corresponding latent vectors, which is given as follows: (4,2) xsp, op = (U p s) (V p o) T + bpowhere Up, Up, Up, IR | S | × K, V p, IR | O | × K and bp, IR | O | 1. | S | and | O | denote the size of subject and object associated with predicate p or. K is the number of latent dimensions and bpo, IR is a distortion term associated with object o. Predicate p, the higher the score of xsp, op, the more similar the units sp and op in embedded low dimensional space, which provides a higher degree of confidence in this fact.

sections.heading: 4.2 Bayesian Personalized Ranking
sections.text: In collaborative filtering, only positive data is known as implicit feedback / binary feedback. − lno Example: In the eCommerce platform, some users only buy, but do not evaluate items. Motivated by [23], we use − p − p − p − p (BPR) based approach to model learning. Especially in the referral system domain, the given user item matrix, the BPR-based approach, the user's preference for purchased items with a higher score is assigned as unobserved triple facts in the knowledge base. We assume that there are not necessarily negative facts, but that they are "less preferable" than the observed ones.For our task, in each predicate p, we refer to the observed subject / object entity pair as (sp, o + p) and not observed as (sp, o + p). The observed facts in our case are the existing link between the specified Gsp and the observed Gp and not observed.

sections.heading: 4.3 Pseudo-code
sections.text: The pseudo-code of our proposed link prediction model is described in algorithm 1. It takes the knowledge graph G and a specific target predicate p as input and generates the low-dimensional latent matrices Up, V p, bp as output. Line 1 constructs the two-sided partial graph of the predicate p, Gp with the entire knowledge graph G. Lines 2-3 calculates the number of subject and object entities as m or n in the resulting two-sided partial graph Gp. Line 4 generates a collection of triple samples with uniform sample technique. Lines 5-7 initializes the matrices Up, V p, bp using the Gaussian distribution with 0 mean and 0.1 standard deviation, with all entries in Up, V p and bp independent. Lines 8-14 update the corresponding rows of matrices Up, V p, bp based on the sampled instance (o, o, each Iteration − p).

sections.heading: 5 Experiments and Results
sections.text: In this section, we present our experimental analysis of the above-mentioned algorithms for thirteen unique predicates in the well-known YAGO2 knowledge graph [12]. We construct a model for each predicate and describe our assessment strategies, including performance metrics and the selection of state-of-the-art methods for benchmarking in Section 5.1. We try to answer two questions through our experiments: Table 1 shows the statistics of different YAGO2 relationships used in our experiments. # Subject and # Object represent the number of subject and object tentities associated with the corresponding predicate. The last column in Table 1 shows the number of facts for each relationship in YAGO2. We run all experiments on a 2.1 GHz machine with 4GB of memory under Linux operating system. The algorithms are implemented in Python language and use NumPy and SciPy libraries for linear algebra operations.

sections.heading: 5.1 Experimental Setting
sections.text: For our experiment to demonstrate the performance of our proposed link prediction model, we use the YAGO2 datasets and multiple evaluation metrics for all the compared algorithms. Specifically, for each relationship, we divide the data into a training part used for model training and a test part used for model evaluation. We apply 5 times the proposed list of recommended objects for the evaluation strategy, where for each subject we randomly remove a fact (a subject pair) and put it in the test set constant and remaining in the training setup Strain. For each subject, the training model generates a ranking of recommended objects for the recommendation task. The evaluation is performed by comparing the recommendation list of each subject and the object tenacity of that subject in the test setup. The web search is used to find regulation parameters, and we set the values of the parameters used in section 4.2 as a starting point.

sections.heading: 5.2 YAGO2 Relation Prediction Performance
sections.text: Figure 1 shows the average link prediction performance for YAGO2 relationships using various methods. Our proposed approach to latent embedding of traits shows a significant improvement over other algorithms for most relationships in YAGO2. For all YAGO2 predictors used in the experiment, our proposed model consistently performs better than the MF-based method, which empirical experience shows is that the paired ranking-based method performs much better on implicit feedback for link recommendation tasks than the mutually regressive method. Compared to the popular MP recommendation method, however, our method performs better on most predictors. For example, our proposed model performs more than ten times better on both HR and ARHR predictors such as "participate," "connect," "HasChild" and "influence."

sections.heading: 5.3 Analysis and Discussion
sections.text: Figure 1 shows that the performance of the link prediction model varies greatly from predicate to predicate in the YAGO2 knowledge base. For example, the HR of the dealsWith predicate is significantly better than "own." Therefore, it is crucial that we quantify model performance in different relationships in a knowledge diagram. Let's recall that our model Mp only takes into account the bifurcated subgraph Gp. Motivated by [20], we investigate the effects of the resulting graph structure of Gp on the performance of Mp.For each predicate p, we calculate multiple graph metrics based on its bifurcated sub-curve Gp, such as graph density, mean degrees and cluster coefficients. Figure 2 shows the quantitative analysis between graph structure and link prediction models Performance of p.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: Inspired by the success of collaborative filtering algorithms for recommendation systems, we propose a latent, function-based embedding model for the task of link prediction in a knowledge graph. Our proposed method provides a measure of "trust" to add a threefold to the knowledge graph. We evaluate our implementation based on the well-known YAGO2 knowledge graph. The experiments show that our approach, based on the Bayesian Personalized Ranking, performs better than two state-of-the-art recommendation system models: Most Popular and Matrix Factorization. We also develop a linear regression model to quantitatively examine the correlation between the performance of the link prediction model itself and various topological metrics of the graph from which the models are constructed. Regression analysis shows a strong correlation between link prediction performance and topological characteristics of the graph, such as graph density, average degree and clustering efficiency, based solely on a prediction prediction model we have developed for the given two parts of the graph.

Since the problem we solve in this paper is similar to one-class item recommendation [23] in recommender systems, we consider the following state-of-the-art oneclass recommendation methods as baseline approaches for comparison.

Link prediction, or predicting the likelihood of a link in a knowledge graph based on prior state is a key research direction within this area. Experimental results on largescale knowledge bases such as YAGO2 show that our approach achieves substantially higher performance than several state-of-art approaches.
